name: purification of wet-process phosphoric acid to industrial grade, product in 85% solution state | phosphoric acid, industrial grade, without water, in 85% solution state | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8889/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of industrial grade phosphoric acid. Phosphoric acid (H3PO4) is mostly used for the production of fertilizers. Other areas of application include the production of industrial phosphates and feedstuffs (Schrödter et al. 2008).;This dataset models the purification of phosphoric acid by solvent extraction to obtain a solution with a 85% H3PO4 content. The inventory is based on data from one production plant, as well as estimations.;References:;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.;Schrödter, K., Bettermann, G., Staffel, T., Wahl, F., Klein, T. and Hofmann, T. 2008. Phosphoric Acid and Phosphates. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.

The activity starts when the fertiliser grade phosphoric acid enters the process.

This activity ends with the production of industrial grade phosphoric acid. The dataset includes the consumption of raw materials, energy uses, infrastructure, and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data from one site in United Kingdom used. No data of other sites within Europe considered.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: For the purification of fertiliser grade phosphoric acid, solvent extraction is the most common process to remove the impurities. The extraction process considered produces an extraction raffinate (in addition to the purified acid), which contains all the impurities. This raffinate is reacted with quicklime to obtain a solid waste containing mainly calcium sulphate and hydroxy apatite. In this solid waste, the metals are locked up in the crystal lattice. The obtained waste is land filled (Landbank 1994). Due to the sulfuric acid added during the extraction, a high yield is achieved: it is about 98% (in % of P2O5 input).;Other possible production processes, such as so-called splitting processes, are not considered in this dataset. In these processes, the yield is much lower (around 50-70%) and the impurities in the aqueous phase are reused in fertiliser production.;References:;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.;Ullmann (2001b) Phosphoric acid and Phosphates. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Sixth Edition, June-2001 Electronic Release (ed. Schrödter K., Bettermann G., Staffel T., Klein T. and Hofmann T.). 6 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/ueic/ull_search_fs.html.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Production of one plant and one process extrapolated to the whole production.

exchanges.description:
Phosphoric acid (H3PO4) is a mineral (inorganic) acid. It is mostly used for the production of fertilizers. Other areas of application include the production of industrial phosphates and feedstuffs (Schrödter et al. 2008).
Reference(s): Schrödter, K., Bettermann, G., Staffel, T., Wahl, F., Klein, T. and Hofmann, T. 2008. Phosphoric Acid and Phosphates. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.

flow.name: phosphoric acid, industrial grade, without water, in 85% solution state
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. Additional assumptions were made in the case of this dataset.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.

exchanges.description:
Data from one relevant plant used.
Calculated based on literature, (Vionnet, S., Quantis Water Database - Technical Report, 2012). Data represents average of 4 roads of production: dihydrate process, hemihydrate process, recrystallisation process and repulping process. Since the data are average of different process roads the processes included might be slightly different in every read. In general it includes the processes: grinding, processing, filtration, concentration, etc. It is assumed that the amount of water used for steam production is same as in the U.S.

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature, (Vionnet, S., Quantis Water Database - Technical Report, 2012). Data represents average of 4 roads of production: dihydrate process, hemihydrate process, recrystallisation process and repulping process. Since the data are average of different process roads the processes included might be slightly different in every read. In general it includes the processes: grinding, processing, filtration, concentration, etc. The process ends when finished phosphoric acid leaves the plant. It is assumed that the amount of water used for steam production is same as in the U.S.
